wikitext.*: {{qtlisten|...as the song of the lark that rises from the [[Door of Night|gates of night]] and pours its voice among the dying [[stars]], seeing the [[sun]] behind the walls of the world...||[[Of Beren and Lúthien]], ''[[The Silmarillion]]''|Christopher Tolkien - Walls of the World.wav}} The '''Walls of the World''' were the walls that surrounded [[Arda]].{{HM|Guide}} It is not clear what lay beyond them and what they separated. [[Nienna]]'s [[Halls of Nienna|halls]] that were "west of [[West]], upon the borders of the world", had windows that looked outward from the walls of the world.{{S|Vala}} After he was defeated in the [[War of Wrath]], [[Morgoth]] was cast outside the Walls, through the [[Door of Night]], to the [[Void|Timeless Void]], and ever since they are guarded.{{S|Earendil}}{{SM|Q19}}, p. 164 ==Other versions of the legendarium== {{quote|They are as ice and glass and steel, being above all imagination of the [[Elves|Children of Earth]] cold, transparent, and hard. They cannot be seen, nor can they be passed, save by the [[Door of Night]].|[[Rúmil of Tirion]], ''The [[Ambarkanta]]''{{SM|5b}}{{rp|235}}}} In earlier versions of the cosmology such as as the [[Ambarkanta]], the Walls of the World were called the '''Ilurambar''' ([[Qenya|Q]], pron. {{IPA|[ˌiluˈrambar]}}) (q.v.) in [[Qenya]] and they bounded the layer of [[Vaiya]].{{LT1|IXn}}, pp. 226-227 This was first mentioned in [[The Book of Lost Tales: Part One]]. Ilurambar derives from ''[[ilu]]-'' meaning "all, the universe"{{LR|Etymologies}}, entry "IL-" and ''rambar'' (plural of ''[[ramba]]'') meaning "walls".{{LR|Etymologies}}, entry "RAMBÁ-" Earlier it was called the '''Wall of Things'''.{{LT1|IX}}, p. 214 The Walls were a shell that fence [[Vaiya]] and the world from emptiness and darkness of the [[Void|Outer Void]]. The World and all its airs were globed inside of them. They were totally impervious and their only opening was the [[Door of Night]] which was guarded by [[Eärendil]].{{rp|237–238}} Tolkien later changed the conception of Ilurambar to '''Eärambar''' ([[Quenya|Q.]] ''Walls of Eä'').{{MR|P2c}}{{rp|62}} Presumably, this means he conceived '''two''' sets of Walls, the [[Walls of the Night|first of which]] separated Arda from the wide space of Eä, while the other separated Eä itself from the Timeless Void.{{rp|64}} ==See also== *[[Ekkaia]] *[[Walls of the Night]] {{References}} [[Category:Arda]] [[Category:Locations in The Book of Lost Tales]] [[Category:Walls]] [[fi:Maailman muurit]]
